claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces type I interferon-linked changes that expand antigen presentation in tumors.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with checkpoint blockade improved tumor control in mouse experiments.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: In the retrospective metastatic cohort, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival during ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.claim: The sensitization effect depends on mRNA-triggered type I interferon signaling rather than lipid particles alone.

evidence.quote: Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Findings from these perturbation controls were produced in preclinical systems and may not translate identically across all human tumors.
